data.text:
By Diane Emeott-Korzen | New Pelican Writer

Pompano Beach – Eighty-five people came out to a Your District, Your Community, Your Vote, candidate forum at Zion Church last week. Incumbent District 4 Commissioner/Vice Mayor Beverly Perkins and contender Mary Scofield Phillips presented their views. A third candidate, Kevin Eason, did not attend. The evening was moderated by Pastor Nathan Austin of Zion Church and Pastor Norman Freeman of Greater Antioch Baptist Church. An estimated 60 percent of District 4 comes from these two congregations. Minister Tim Griffith organized the event, sponsored by Faith In Florida.

Questions

What do you feel you offer the community that you are worthy of being elected/re-elected?

Perkins listed a number of accomplishments during her tenure on the commission since 2016. For example, the new Fire Station 61 will be opening soon. Liberty Park lights are completed as is the $4.5 million Apollo Park. Pompano has a new community court at Annie Weaver Center with a judge there twice a month presiding over homlessness and misdemeanor crime cases. In Mitchell Moore Park there is going to be a youth development center.

Philips said, “There are a lot of things we need in the community” – more senior housing; workforce housing. Phillips would like the city to change its zoning code to allow tiny houses; so an adult child or senior parent having trouble affording their own place could live on the same property as their family. Also, she supports fostering acting and singing programs at the Esther Rolle Museum.

Both Perkins and Phillips want more black-owned businesses on Martin Luther King Boulevard, and grants for local nonprofit organizations.

How are you going to get millennials to vote?

Perkins said, “Kids, starting in school and the churches, should be taught the importance of voting. When we were kids, kids went with their parents to vote. We don’t do that anymore, [but they can be taught.]”

Phillips said, “We need to work pretty hard to change things. Millennials, if you give them some entertainment, some way to engage them, you can teach them.”

Where do you get funding when the commission doesn’t vote with you?

Perkins said, “There is plenty of funding in the school board that doesn’t trickle down to Northwest Pompano. Sanders Park Elementary School, C. Robert Markham Elementary School, and Blanche Ely High School all need funding.”

Phillips said the 33069 zip code is 67.7 percent black and 42.42 percent white, with 3.2 percent unemployment. “I’m a lifelong learner. I enjoy it. As a realtor, a lot of information comes across my desk.”

We have very passionate people, a lot of division. How can we move this community back together, to bring back unity?

Phillips said, “I’m an optimist. I think we can come together. I like the idea of bringing back the North Broward NAACP.”

Perkins said, “I think we need more than the NAACP to get us back on the right track in Pompano. I see trash on the streets, different issues. As a leader, you have to know when to lead, when to follow. To take yourself out of it when working together.”

What can you do for more jobs, opening up the youth community, teaching kids to be industrious, leading by example?

Perkins said, “We have 19,000 residents of District 4 and only 9,000 registered voters. A lot of seniors have died out. They are not being replaced with younger people, who need to know the importance of voting.”

Phillips said, “I have a nonprofit. I’ve been unable to get money from the City of Pompano Beach since 2008. We need to make sure money is put into a fund.”

What can you both do to collaborate, work together with others, make sure the District 4 agenda is passed?

Perkins said, “I always believe in collegiate voting. I believe whatever a commissioner asks for, for their district, I support it. Also, if you have a concern, let other commissioners know. I share on the dais what the community tells me to say. Right now, all they hear from is just me.”

Phillips replied, “A lot of times, to get what you want, it’s how you approach people. And it needs to make sense to them. My approach is different. I would outline why they should support it. Why it’s important to the community. It’s a give-and-take. It’s politics.”

Pompano has a problem with homelessness. What can be done?

Perkins said, “There is a jail here in Pompano. Next to it is a facility to clothe and house the homeless. We do have a real problem with the homeless. There is a number to call — 954-357-5686. They have pushed them back. They used to be at the beach. Now they are west of Federal Highway.”

Phillips said, “Right in front of my office, every week, I see different homeless faces. I’m told Boca drops off their homeless in Pompano Beach. If so, they need to provide resources. Send the people back to where they came from. Some are mentally ill, some are on drugs, their family kicks them out because they won’t do right.”

After people get arrested, who helps them [clear their records for jobs, housing]?

Perkins said, “ I’ve had meetings at E. Pat Larkins. We spend $50 million per year on BSO. We do not see results in the Northwest community.

Phillips said, “We can only expunge one felony [from a person’s record]. We do it every year. The rest has to be done at the state level.”
